substrateUtilizationMethod: Set the sponge flat on the desk with the yellow side facing upward directly in front of the keyboard. Press the keyboard forward so its front edge compresses the sponge, then lift and roll upward while continuing to compress.
expectedHapticFeedback: Using the pitchfork to thrust into haystack. Light, cushion-like resistance.
harmony_explanation: Soft compressible sponge gives hay-like feel; width is moderate (≈7 cm) so centre alignment needed but still easier than a can. Consistent contact if placed carefully.
expressivity_explanation: The sponge compresses smoothly and can deform several millimeters, providing soft, graded resistance that changes with depth and speed—quite evocative of thrusting into loose hay.
realism_explanation: Sponge compresses softly and rebounds, giving a light cushion resistance similar to penetrating hay. Limited depth and small area keep realism moderate.

physicalContactObject: compact black mechanical keyboard with one red key cap
contactUtilizationMethod: Place both hands on the outer sides of the keyboard, press forward, then lift and roll the front edge upward in a coordinated motion (not sure whether it is applicable)
substrateUtilizationMethod: Place the brush flat with the bristles pointing toward the keyboard. Press the keyboard forward so its front edge sinks into the bristles, then lift and roll upward while keeping the bristles engaged.
expectedHapticFeedback: Using the pitchfork to thrust into haystack. Light, cushion-like resistance.
harmony_explanation: Brush length nearly equals keyboard, and bristles give soft penetration sensation similar to hay strands, producing good timing and feel.
expressivity_explanation: Dense bristles allow penetration with light, springy resistance that increases with depth, giving textural variation analogous to hay, though total travel is limited to bristle length.
realism_explanation: Long bristles deflect and give way, imitating individual hay strands being parted by tines. Depth is shallow and keyboard edge flattens bristles, so realism is moderate rather than high.

physicalContactObject: compact black mechanical keyboard with one red key cap
physicalSubstrateObject: pair of scissors with black and yellow handles
contactUtilizationMethod: Place both hands on the outer sides of the keyboard, press forward, then lift and roll the front edge upward in a coordinated motion (not sure whether it is applicable)
substrateUtilizationMethod: Close the scissors and lay them flat with the handles pointing away from you, blades toward you, one hand-width in front of the keyboard. Push the keyboard forward so its front edge meets the cushioned handle loops, then lift and roll upward over them.
expectedHapticFeedback: Using the pitchfork to thrust into haystack. Light, cushion-like resistance.
harmony_explanation: Tiny contact area (handles only) makes hits inconsistent; hard metal/plastic also discourages strong thrusts. Spatial synchrony poor.
expressivity_explanation: Rubberized handle loops are narrow and mostly rigid; contact area is tiny, so feedback is localized and does not emulate fluffy bulk.
realism_explanation: Mostly hard metal/plastic with tiny rubber inserts; overall interaction is rigid and localized, not cushiony.

physicalContactObject: compact black mechanical keyboard with one red key cap
physicalSubstrateObject: cylindrical metal calibration weight labeled M 500g
contactUtilizationMethod: Place both hands on the outer sides of the keyboard, press forward, then lift and roll the front edge upward in a coordinated motion (not sure whether it is applicable)
substrateUtilizationMethod: Stand the calibration weight upright directly in front of the keyboard. Press the keyboard forward until its front edge contacts the polished cylindrical side, then lift and roll upward along the curved surface.
expectedHapticFeedback: Using the pitchfork to thrust into haystack. Light, cushion-like resistance.
harmony_explanation: Only 4 cm diameter, so easy to miss and offers no cushion. Contact is hard and point-like, often breaking temporal alignment.
expressivity_explanation: Solid steel weight offers zero compliance and tiny contact patch—no resemblance to hay’s soft give.
realism_explanation: Solid steel gives zero compliance; sensation completely mismatches loose hay.

physicalContactObject: compact black mechanical keyboard with one red key cap
physicalSubstrateObject: plush green turtle-shell shaped cushion with white rim
contactUtilizationMethod: Place both hands on the outer sides of the keyboard, press forward, then lift and roll the front edge upward in a coordinated motion (not sure whether it is applicable)
substrateUtilizationMethod: Place the plush turtle cushion on the desk directly in front of the keyboard with the green shell facing you. Press the keyboard forward so its front edge buries slightly into the plush surface, then lift and roll upward while compressing the cushion.
expectedHapticFeedback: Using the pitchfork to thrust into haystack. Light, cushion-like resistance.
harmony_explanation: Large plush area ensures keyboard always meets cushion, and compressibility mirrors hay softness, giving strong temporal and spatial harmony.
expressivity_explanation: Large plush cushion compresses deeply and unevenly, letting the keyboard sink in and create variable force feedback akin to piercing and lifting hay, giving good expressivity.
realism_explanation: Large plush offers deep, soft yield and low spring constant close to hay. Scale of cushion allows broader motion. Keyboard shape still diverges from long pitchfork, preventing perfect illusion.

physicalContactObject: compact black mechanical keyboard with one red key cap
physicalSubstrateObject: blue two-seater bench with black metal armrests
contactUtilizationMethod: Place both hands on the outer sides of the keyboard, press forward, then lift and roll the front edge upward in a coordinated motion (not sure whether it is applicable)
substrateUtilizationMethod: Kneel or sit in front of the bench seat. Hold the keyboard at seat height and press its front edge into the bench’s fabric cushion, then lift and roll upward while compressing the upholstery.
expectedHapticFeedback: Using the pitchfork to thrust into haystack. Light, cushion-like resistance.
harmony_explanation: Bench seat is extremely wide and plush; every thrust or lift naturally contacts the cushion precisely when visual collision occurs, maximizing synchrony.
expressivity_explanation: The seat cushion is broad and yields gradually, allowing deep penetration and force variation that map well to the sensation of thrusting into a haystack.
realism_explanation: Thick foam cushion compresses substantially, delivering the soft resistance typical of hay. Large surface supports wide motion. Main limitation is still the short, flat keyboard acting as proxy for long tines.

physicalContactObject: compact black mechanical keyboard with one red key cap
physicalSubstrateObject: transparent umbrella with white curved handle
contactUtilizationMethod: Place both hands on the outer sides of the keyboard, press forward, then lift and roll the front edge upward in a coordinated motion (not sure whether it is applicable)
substrateUtilizationMethod: Lay the closed umbrella horizontally on a flat surface, shaft perpendicular to the keyboard and handle away. Press the keyboard forward so its front edge climbs the cylindrical canopy, then lift and roll upward over the curved surface.
expectedHapticFeedback: Using the pitchfork to thrust into haystack. Light, cushion-like resistance.
harmony_explanation: Umbrella shaft gives continuous bar but only ≈3 cm thick; keyboard can slip above or below if not aligned, so contact consistency is moderate.
expressivity_explanation: Plastic canopy is thin but still feels mostly rigid when rolled over; only slight flex, so minimal cushion-like variation.
realism_explanation: Umbrella shaft and canopy are rigid; provides no cushion or penetration feel.

physicalContactObject: compact black mechanical keyboard with one red key cap
contactUtilizationMethod: Place both hands on the outer sides of the keyboard, press forward, then lift and roll the front edge upward in a coordinated motion (not sure whether it is applicable)
substrateUtilizationMethod: Position the keyboard at the edge of the bean bag’s sidewall. Press its front edge into the soft fabric so it sinks into the filling, then lift and roll the keyboard upward while maintaining pressure against the bag.
expectedHapticFeedback: Using the pitchfork to thrust into haystack. Light, cushion-like resistance.
harmony_explanation: Huge, yielding surface behaves very much like a haystack; keyboard contact is guaranteed and timing naturally matches visual collision, providing excellent harmony.
expressivity_explanation: Loose fill inside the bean bag shifts and flows around the keyboard edge, providing deep, soft resistance with rich variation—very evocative of piercing and lifting hay.
realism_explanation: Bean bag offers deep, low-density resistance that closely mimics thrusting through hay. Size enables larger arm motion. Keyboard proxy still limits fidelity somewhat.
